page.title: 12FARMING IN THE HIGH WEALD
page.content: Clearance of the forest of{The Weald for agriculture has been taking place since{Saxon times}and by 1350 it had almost reached its present extent. Today it is mostly used for{dairy {farming}as the soil is unsuitable for growing cereals or other crops profitably. The main crop is{intensive {grass}but odd fields of barley, oats or potatoes are grown on some farms. The{EEC milk quota}introduced in 1984 has halted expansion and cut milk farm sales by 11% so farmers are trying to diversify to keep in profit. The grass is grazed, some{hay}made but mostly it is made into{silage}for the dairy herd in winter. This is mostly put into clamps but latterly some is baled and put in plastic sacks. Most herds are {Friesians,}but{Jerseys}are bred at Duckyls Farm and{Guernseys}at Old House Farm and are exhibited at shows.
